questions.question_text: A network administrator wants to implement security zones in the corporate network to control access to only individuals inside of the corporation. Which of the following security zones is the best solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Trusted

Explanation:

A trusted security zone is typically used for resources that are accessible only to individuals inside the corporation or its internal network. This zone allows for more strict access controls, ensuring that only authorized internal users can access specific resources, thus providing the highest level of security for sensitive data and services.

questions.question_text: Which of the following network devices converts wireless signals to electronic signals?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
An access point receives wireless signals from devices like smartphones and laptops and then translates them into electronic signals that can be understood by a wired network

Selected Answer: C
C. Access point.
Access point is a wireless device that you can connect to wirelessly while roaming around a building

questions.question_text: A network administrator deployed wireless networking in the office area. When users visit the outdoor patio and try to download emails with large attachments or stream training videos, they notice buffering issues. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Signal Degradation because they are too far from the wireless network

questions.question_text: Which of the following activities would have groups from different departments evaluate the disaster recovery process?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Tabletop exercises

Explanation:

Tabletop exercises are structured, discussion-based activities where different departments or teams (such as IT, management, and other key stakeholders) come together to evaluate and walk through the disaster recovery process. These exercises allow participants to discuss their roles, responsibilities, and responses to various disaster scenarios, helping to identify gaps in the process and improve coordination across departments

questions.question_text: Which of the following routing protocols uses an autonomous system number?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
EIGRP uses autonomous system number, but it is mainly used for identification and redistribution purposes and not for core path selection like BGP.

Selected Answer: C
C. BGP. According to CompTIA: "Autonomous system numbers (ASN) are allocated to ISPs by IANA via the various regional registries. BGP is a type of exterior gateway protocol (in fact, it replaced a protocol named EGP) for communications between routers in separate autonomous systems. When BGP is used within an AS, it is referred to as Interior BGP (IBGP), and when implemented between autonomous systems, it is referred to as Exterior BGP (EBGP)." Refeerance CompTIA Network + Study Guide.

Selected Answer: C
I looked up other sources and I consistently found BGP to be the answer.

comments.content: C: BGP = The answer, Mistakingly nominated the wrong box

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Yes, EIGRP (Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol) does use an autonomous system number (ASN) to identify the collection of routers that share routing information within a specific routing domain; according to :-Generative AI
 So Does BGP: Yes, BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) utilizes an Autonomous System Number (ASN) to identify each network
So , what is the right answer????
Is there anybody who is willing to stick his/her neck out for this?

Selected Answer: C
C. BGP

BGP (Border Gateway Protocol) is the routing protocol that uses an Autonomous System Number (ASN). This is used to identify unique networks or groups of networks in different organizations and is critical for inter-domain routing between different ASes on the internet
